Magnetic nanostructure-anchored mixed-donor ligand system based on carboxamide and N-heterocyclic thiones: An efficient support of CuI catalyst for synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines in eutectic medium This article is dedicated to memory of Ebrahim Shojaee. Graphical abstract A Cu-incorporated nanocatalyst has been developed by immobilizing copper iodide on a magnetically retrievable mixed-donor ligand system, containing carboxamide, imidazolidine-2-thione and imidazole-2-thione donor groups and characterized by various analysis techniques such as FT-IR, XRD, FE-SEM, EDX elemental mapping, TEM, ICP-OES, TGA, and VSM. The versatility of the synthesized nanocatalyst has been demonstrated for the one-pot synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine derivatives via three-component reaction of 2-aminopyridines, aldehydes and alkynes using tetrabutyl ammonium bromide/glycerol (TBAB/glycerol) deep eutectic mixture as a sustainable medium. The nanocatalyst has exhibited high activity and stability under the reaction conditions with a negligible copper leaching, which can be due to the effective coordination interaction between the oxygen atom of carbonyl group as well as the sulfur atoms of thiocarbonyl groups in the supported ligand with copper iodide. The catalyst system can be readily recovered and successfully reused at least five times. Eco-friendly conditions, solvent recoverability, higher TON, wide functional group tolerance and lower E factor (0.2) are some other merits of the present work. Keywords Organocopper(I) catalyst Magnetic nanostructure N-Heterocyclic thiones Carboxamide Deep eutectic solvent Imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines 1 Introduction During the past decades, extensive efforts have been placed toward the development of efficient and recyclable metal catalytic systems, which minimize possible pollution resulting from toxic metal discharge in homogeneous synthetic protocols to achieve the goals of green and sustainable chemistry. Despite the priority of homogeneous catalysts in terms of activity and selectivity over their heterogeneous counterparts, they suffer from a number of problems, such as difficult catalyst recovery, high cost, and oxygen sensitivity [1]. In this aspect, magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) are well known to be the most promising heterogeneous nanostructures for catalytic purposes owing to their unique properties, including the high surface area, high stability, low toxicity, and low cost in addition to facile separation by magnetic force [2]. Among the reported metal catalysts, copper catalysis has found great importance in the methodology field [3,4]. A wide range of copper complexes incorporating N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands derived from imidazolium salts, have been used in organic synthesis, which have mostly shown significant catalytic activity [5–7]. Imidazole-2-thiones are another class of N-heterocyclic compounds, which can be prepared from the imidazolium salts, similar to NHC–copper complexes. The imidazolium salts are subjected to treatment with base and subsequently with sulfur powder to produce N, N′-disubstituted imidazole-2-thiones [8]. These compounds due to their tunable electronic and steric properties have attracted much attention as ligand in transition metal catalysis [9]. The CS double bond in these ligands exhibits high thermal and chemical stability. In this regard, neutral bidentate ligands bridged by CH2 unit have also been extensively studied [10,11]. The sulfur in the bidentate imidazole-2-thione-based ligands can create several coordination modes for transition metal species, depending on different conditions. In some complexes, an eight-membered metallacycle is formed with the metal center [12]. In other cases, these bidentate ligands are able to bridge two metal centers [13–15]. In the last decade, a variety of Pd, Ni and Cu complexes incorporating N-heterocyclic thione donor groups have been used in transition metal catalysis [9,16–18]. While all them have so far been used as homogeneous catalysts in organic transformations, thereby, they may be associated with some drawbacks as mentioned above. Imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines are a subgroup of the nitrogen‐containing bicyclic compounds mainly occurred in a wide range of natural products and biologically important compounds possessing diverse pharmaceutical properties. They have also been found to act as β-amyloid formation inhibitors [19], bradykinin B2 receptor antagonists [20], cardiotonic agents [21], and so on. In particular, imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine is an essential fragment present in many known drug molecules, including alpidem (anxiolytic), zolpidem (hypnotic) [22], necopidem (anxiolytic drug), and so on [23]. In view of their remarkable medicinal importance as well as their prevalence in dyes [24], ligands for metal catalysts [25], and optoelectronics [26], numerous synthetic protocols have been developed to efficiently access imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines [27]. Among the extensive related reports, the main focus of research has been on A3-coupling reactions to afford imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine derivatives via 5-exo-dig cyclization. After the pioneering work by Gevorgyan and Chernyak [28], various homogeneous catalysts have been employed for the synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine derivatives, such as CuSO4/p-TsOH [29], InBr3/Et3N [30], CuSO4/glucose [31], I2 [32], and CuSO4/NaOAs [33]. Further, in the area of heterogeneous catalysis, many efforts have been devoted to synthesis of these motifs and a variety of recyclable catalytic systems, denoted by Cu–Mn [34], nano-Fe3O4-KHSO4.SiO2 [35], MNPs@BiimCu [36], LCu′ (Cu-MOF) [37], and PEA-PSA@CuI [38] have been developed. Also, there is a report on the synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines using a recyclable catalytic system comprising CuFeO2 MNPs in citric acid–dimethylurea melt [39]. Despite their effectiveness, some of the reported methodologies encounter one or more drawbacks, such as the use of toxic organic solvents or additives, moisture sensitivity, long reaction times, tedious catalyst separation/recovery processes (non-recoverable in some cases), and unsatisfactory yields of the products. A strategic place within the framework of green and sustainable chemistry relates to solvents. Over the past decade, deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have emerged as one of the most promising sustainable reaction media alternative to conventional solvents in organic synthesis [40,41]. DESs are mostly composed by simple mixing and gently heating a neutral hydrogen-bond donor (HBD) and a quaternary ammonium salt in a specific molar ratio. Many attempts have been made to apply DESs in the field of metal-catalyzed organic transformations, particularly in recent years [39,42–45]. Based on the above considerations, it can be envisaged that the development of an efficient, green and sustainable approach for the synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines will be highly desirable. With this in mind and as part of our continued efforts on the development of environmentally benign protocols for organic catalytic synthesis [46–49], in this work, we aimed to design and synthesize a highly active and recyclable Cu-incorporated nanocatalyst by immobilizing copper iodide on a magnetic mixed-donor ligand system, containing carboxamide, imidazolidine-2-thione and imidazole-2-thione donor groups. The synthesized nanoparticles were successfully identified and then applied to the one-pot synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines via three-component reactions of 2-aminopyridines, aldehydes and alkynes in TBAB/glycerol DES as a sustainable, biocompatible, and recyclable promoting medium. 2 Experimental section 2.1 General remarks All chemicals were purchased from Merck and Aldrich companies and used directly without further purification. All reported yields are isolated yields. Preparative thin-layer chromatography (TLC) was performed on thin glass plates coated with silica gel 60 F-254 (0.2 mm) as the solid phase. Infrared spectra (IR) were recorded using KBr pellet method on a NICOLET FT-IR 100 spectrometer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained in order to study the morphology and size of the nanocatalyst using a TESCAN MIRA III FE-SEM instrument. To study elemental composition of the nanocatalyst, the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) technique was performed in conjunction with SEM. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained at room temperature using a Philips X-pert MPD diffractometer with Co Kα radiation (α = 1.78897 A°), scanning rate of 0.02 °/s, 40 kV voltage and 40 mA current over the range of 10−90 ° for 2θ. The magnetic property of the nanoparticles was studied using a vibrating magnetometer/alternating gradient force magnetometer (VSM/AGFM, MDK Co., Iran). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis was carried out at 200 kV (Philips model CM300). Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was recorded using a thermal analyzer (SDT Q600) with a heating rate of 20 °C min−1 over a temperature range of 25−800 °C under flowing argon. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis was performed using a Varlan Vista-Pro ICP-OE spectrometer. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance (DRX 300 and 500 MHz) in pure deuterated CDCl3 solvent with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as internal standard. 2.2 Procedure for preparation of nanocatalyst 2.2.1 Preparation of silica-coated magnetite nanoparticles (MNPs) Silica-coated magnetite nanoparticles were prepared by alkaline hydrolysis of iron(II) chloride and iron(III) chloride (with a molar ratio of 1:2), followed by treatment with tetraethyl orthosilicate in alkaline aqueous medium according to the previously reported procedure [47]. 2.2.2 Synthesis of 1-((1H-imidazol-1-yl)methyl)imidazolidine-2-thione (1) A solution of imidazole (0.68 g, 10 mmol) and formalin (37 %; 10 mmol) in ethanol (25 mL) were stirred in the presence of p-toluenesulfonic acid (p-TSA.H2O, 20 mol%) as an acid catalyst at room temperature (RT) for an appropriate time (20 min). Then, an ethanolic solution (25 mL) of imidazolidine-2-thione (1.02 g, 10 mmol) was added dropwise with constant vigorous stirring. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12 h. After completion of the reaction as indicated by TLC, the mixture was concentrated. The pure product was obtained by chromatography on silica gel (isolated yield: 85 %). MS (EI, 70 eV): m/z (%): 182 (M+). 2.2.3 Preparation of 3-((1H-imidazol-1-yl)methyl)-N-propyl-2-thioxoimidazolidine-1-carboxamide immobilized on MNP (MNP-IMPTC) (2) A mixture of precursor 1 (0.9 g, 5 mmol) and triethylamine (0.52 g, 5.2 mmol) in dry acetonitrile (20 mL) was stirred for 20 min. Then, 5 mmol (1.23 g) of triethoxy(3-isocyanatopropyl)silane (TESPIC) in dry acetonitrile (20 mL) was added dropwise over a period of 15 min. The resultant mixture was heated to reflux overnight under an argon atmosphere. The solvent was then removed by rotatory evaporation under reduced pressure, and the residue was washed with dry diethyl ether, followed by drying at 40 °C under vacuum for 2 h to obtain the 3-((1H-imidazol-1-yl)methyl)-2-thioxo-N-(3-(triethoxysilyl)propyl)imidazolidine-1-carboxamide intermediate. To synthesize compound 2, MNPs (1.0 g) were dispersed in dry ethanol (25 mL) by sonication for 20 min. Then, an ethanolic solution (25 mL) of the as-prepared intermediate (1.28 g, 3 mmol) was added. The resulting suspension was heated to reflux under argon atmosphere for 18 h. After the specified time, the reaction mixture was cooled down to room temperature, and the resulting nanoparticles were magnetically separated and washed successively with water and ethanol before being oven-dried at 60 °C for 6 h. 2.2.4 Preparation of MNP-supported 3-((3-methyl-2-thioxo-2,3-dihydro-1H-imidazol-1-yl)methyl)-N-propyl-2-thioxoimidazolidine-1-carboxamide (MNP-TIMPTC) (3) and immobilization of copper iodide (MNP-TIMPTC-CuI) (4) Compound 2 (1.0 g) was dispersed in 25 ml of dry toluene by sonication for 10 min before treating with 3 mmol of methyl iodide under bath cooling condition (5 °C). The resultant mixture was then stirred for 6 h at room temperature in a sealed flask. After the specified time, the nanoparticles were magnetically filtrated and washed with toluene and diethyl ether before being dried under vacuum. In the next step, a 100 ml round-bottomed flask fitted with a reflux condenser was charged with the as-prepared product (1.0 g), sulfur powder (0.1 g, 3 mmol), potassium carbonate (0.34 g, 2.5 mmol) and 50 ml methanol as solvent. The mixture was heated to reflux for 24 h. Then, the functionalized nanoparticles (3) were magnetically separated and washed successively with water, ethanol and diethyl ether before being oven-dried at 60 °C for 6 h. In continue, to a freshly prepared solution of copper iodide (0.19 g, 1 mmol) in dry acetonitrile, well-dispersed nanoparticles 3 (1.0 g) were added and the resulting dispersion was kept stirring at 40 °C for 12 h under an argon atmosphere. The resultant MNP-TIMPTC-CuI (4) was collected with an external magnet and washed consecutively with acetonitrile, ethanol and finally acetone. It was dried at 50 °C for 6 h under vacuum to afford MNP-TIMPTC-CuI nanocatalyst. 2.3 Preparation of DESs DESs were prepared according to the methods reported in the literatures [7,50–52]. In order to synthesize DESs, the previously specified molar ratios of HBD (ethylene glycol or glycerol) and HBA (choline chloride, sodium acetate, choline acetate and TBAB) were mixed and then heated at 80 °C under continuous stirring until a homogeneous colorless liquid was formed. The obtained DESs were used in reactions without any purification. 2.4 General procedure for the synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine derivatives In a test tube equipped with a stir bar, a mixture of 2-aminopyridine (1.0 mmol) and benzaldehyde (1.05 mmol) was stirred (in some cases in presence of DES at 100 °C) for 15−20 min, subsequently phenyl acetylene (1.1 mmol), MNP-TIMPTC-CuI (20 mg, 0.76 mol %) and TBAB/glycerol (1:9, 2 mL) were added to the mixture and continued stirring at 110 °C for an appropriate time. After completion of the reaction as indicated by TLC, the reaction mixture was cooled to ambient temperature and magnetically decanted, followed by washing the residue with ethanol and water and dried under vacuum to recover the catalyst for reuse in subsequent runs under the same conditions. The decanted mixture was diluted with water (2 mL) and extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 5 mL) and then the combined organic phases were dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude products were purified by chromatography on silica gel to afford the desired products. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst preparation The synthesis of the MNP-TIMPTC-CuI nanocatalyst was accomplished via the following steps, as shown in Scheme 1 . At first, magnetite nanoparticles were synthesized according to the conventional chemical co-precipitation procedure. Then, the silica coating of the magnetite nanoparticles was performed to improve the chemical stability and biocompatibility of them. On the other hand, the reaction of imidazolidine-2-thione with imidazole in the presence of formalin resulted in the formation of the compound 1, which was followed by treatment with TESPIC. In continuing, the silica coated magnetite nanoparticles were functionalized with the as-synthesized compound. The final structure of the MNP-TIMPTC-CuI nanocatalyst (4) was obtained through the treatment of MNP-IMPTC (2) with methyl iodide and subsequently elemental sulfur under alkaline conditions, followed by exposure to copper iodide. 3.2 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1 shows the FT-IR spectra of compound 1, TESPIC, compound 2, Fe3O4@SiO2, MNP-TIMPTC and MNP-TIMPTC-CuI nanoparticles in the 400–4000 cm−1 wave number range. In Fig. 1a, for compound 1, the characteristic peaks appearing at 1371, 1527, and 1641 are respectively related to the stretching vibrations of CS, CC and CN. The peaks present at 2879 and 3046 cm−1 are due to CH stretching vibrations. As shown in Fig. 1b, the sharp band appearing at 2272 cm−1 is owing to stretching vibration of NCO in TESPIC. After addition of compound 1 to TESPIC, the peak belonging to the isocyanate group disappeared, while new bands emerged at 1388 cm−1 (CS stretching vibration), 1531 cm−1 (CC stretching vibration), 1648 cm−1 (CN stretching vibration), 1702 cm−1 (CO stretching vibration), and 3237 cm−1 (stretching vibration of NH) in FT-IR spectrum of compound 2, as shown in Fig. 1c. Also, the peaks at 2969 and 3056 cm−1 are attributed to CH stretching vibrations. As seen in Figs. 1d-f, the characteristic peaks appearing at 581, 1090 and 3422 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibrations of FeO, SiOSi and OH (surface hydroxyl groups and physically adsorbed water) in Fe3O4@SiO2 nanoparticles. After the compound 2 was immobilized on the surface of the MNPs, the mentioned absorption bands corresponding to C = O, CN, CC and CS vibrations for compound 2, were slightly shifted and appeared at 1695, 1643, 1540 and 1384 cm−1, respectively in spectrum of MNP-IMPTC (Fig. 1e). After treating MNP-IMPTC with copper iodide, it was occurred a negative shift in absorption frequency of CO as well as CS and their bands were appeared at 1685 cm−1 and 1370 cm−1, respectively. Further, a slight decrease was observed in the intensity of the absorption peaks corresponding to the stretching vibrations of CO and CS bonds in the spectrum of MNP-TIMPTC-CuI (Fig. 1f). According to these results and what has been reported in the related published articles, the coordination chemistry of final complexes can be estimated to be three-coordinated copper(I) complex with a symmetrical environment for the N-heterocyclic thiones as ligand. The characteristic weak peak at 670 cm−1 for copper iodide did not appear due to the overlapping bands around 650–700 cm−1. Although, the presence of copper can be confirmed by elemental analyses. All the significant peaks of the grafted organic moiety as well as the peaks at 587 and 1093 cm−1 due to FeO and SiOSi bonds are present in the spectrum of MNP-TIMPTC-CuI [15,49,53]. The crystallinity and phase purity of the nanoparticles were assessed using X-ray diffraction technique (Fig. 2 a–c). As depicted in XRD patterns of Fe3O4, MNP and MNP-TIMPTC-CuI, diffraction peaks marked by the indices (220), (311), (400), (422), (511) and (440) which appeared at 2θ values of 35.27 °, 41.73 °, 50.97 °, 63.47 °, 67.87 ° and 74.73 °, respectively, can indicate the crystalline structure of the cubic magnetite (JCPDS file no.19−0629). As shown in XRD patterns b and c, the broad peaks in the 2θ range from 21 ° to 30 ° are indexed to reflection of the silica phase, demonstrating the core–shell structure of the prepared MNPs. The XRD patterns represent that the crystalline structure of Fe3O4 remains intact after each modification with organic group and CuI species. In the XRD pattern of MNP-TIMPTC-CuI, the diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 25.5 °, 29.5 °, 42.2 °, 50.0 °, 61.2 °, 67.45 ° and 77.20 ° can be attributed to cubic copper iodide (JCPDS card no. 01–076‐0207), which evidences the presence of copper iodide complex in the structure of the catalyst (Fig. 2c) [36]. The surface morphology of nanoparticles was investigated by scanning electron microscopy. As depicted in the inset of Fig. 3 a, nano-Fe3O4 has been prepared with uniform-sized particles and spherical morphology. After the coating of organic moiety, morphology remained intact (Fig. 3a). Also, when MNP-TIMPTC material was treated with Cu (I) species, no significant surface change was observed. As shown in the FE-SEM image of MNP-TIMPTC-CuI, the as-synthesized nanostructure has a nearly spherical morphology with a mean diameter of 33 nm (Fig. 3b). The appearance of nanoparticles in the aggregated form can be due to the magnetic nature of them [47]. To identify the elemental composition of MNP-TIMPTC-CuI, the energy-dispersive X-ray analysis was performed. As presented in Fig. 3c, the EDX spectrum of the catalyst clearly confirms that it has been consisted of the expected elements, including carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, silicon, sulfur, iron, copper and iodine with wt% of 14.58, 8.28, 37.36, 19.98, 2.21, 12.26, 2.06 and 3.27, respectively. TEM images of the MNP-TIMPTC-CuI nanocatalyst are illustrated at different magnifications in Fig. 4 a and b. As shown in the TEM images, the dark-coloured spots appearing nearly spherical are attributed to the core of the nanoparticles (nano‐Fe3O4), while the colorless regions represent the shell layer coated on the iron oxide nanoparticles (SiO2-TIMPTC-CuI). Moreover, the density and distribution of the Fe, Si, C, O, N, S, Cu and I elements present in the MNP-TIMPTC-CuI structure were evaluated using EDX mapping analysis (Fig. 4c). The thermogravimetric analysis was performed to investigate the thermal behaviors of Fe3O4 (a), MNP-IMPTC (d) and MNP-TIMPTC-CuI (Fig. 5 ). As seen in Fig. 5a and b, the TGA curves of bare Fe3O4 nanoparticles and MNP-IMPTC show a slight weight loss at temperatures below 200 °C, which can be exclusively attributed to the loss of physically adsorbed water. The TGA curve of MNP-IMPTC shows another weight loss (14.55 wt%) in the 200−600 °C temperature range, indicating the decomposition of the grafted organic groups. As depicted in Fig. 5c, the TGA curve of MNP-TIMPTC-CuI indicates three stage weight loss. In the first stage, 4% weight loss at temperatures below 150 °C is due to the release of the adsorbed moisture, whereas the major weight loss (18.87 wt%) appears in the 160−600 °C temperature range, which can be attributed to the decomposition of organic moieties immobilized on MNPs. The third weight loss that has occurred at higher temperatures can be ascribed to iodine sublimation (melting point of CuI: 602 °C). According to the TGA results, the content of organic moiety in the MNP-TIMPTC-CuI catalyst is evaluated to be 0.6 mmol g−1. Also, the copper content in the catalyst structure is estimated to be 0.40 mmol g−1. By comparing the amount of weight loss in the TGA curves of MNP-IMPTC and MNP-TIMPTC-CuI over the temperature range 200−750 °C, it could be possible to deduce the successful conversion of MNP-IMPTC to MNP-TIMPTC-CuI [47]. Furthermore, the exact amount of copper present in the MNP-TIMPTC-CuI structure has been found to be 0.38 mmol g−1 using inductively coupled plasma analysis. The magnetic properties of the as-synthesized nanoparticles were characterized in an applied magnetic field sweeping from -10 K to 10 K Oe at room temperature using a vibrating sample magnetometer. Fig. 6 shows the magnetic hysteresis curves of the Fe3O4, Fe3O4@SiO2 and MNP-TIMPTC-CuI materials. The VSM results exhibited neither remanence nor coercivity at room temperature, implying the superparamagnetic property of the nanoparticles. The saturation magnetization (Ms) values of bare iron oxide, silica coted iron oxide and the as‐synthesized MNP-TIMPTC-CuI are 62, 31.86 and 23.77 emu g−1, respectively. Decrease in the Ms value of MNP-TIMPTC-CuI in comparison with that of the bare Fe3O4 nanoparticles can be attributed to the presence of non-magnetic species such as silica shell and copper iodide complex on the surface of the Fe3O4 nanoparticles. Nevertheless, the magnetic separation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture could be easily achieved by applying an external magnetic field. 3.3 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity of the synthesized MNP-TIMPTC-CuI was probed by the three-component coupling reaction of phenylacetylene, benzaldehyde, and 2-aminopyridine as a model reaction to form imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine derivatives. The results are shown in Table 1 . In an initial experiment, in the absence of any catalyst, the reaction was unable to proceed to afford the expected product even after heating the reaction mixture for 12 h in TBAB/glycerol (1:9) (Table 1, entry 1). Evidently, almost no desired product would be detected if the reaction occurred in the presence of bare MNPs (Table 1, entry 2). It can be clearly seen in Table 1 that CuI was inferior to MNP-TIMPTC-CuI in terms of efficiency and time (entries 3, 4). Then we turned our attention to investigate the influence of solvent on the reaction. By carrying out the model reaction in the presence of MNP-TIMPTC-CuI (0.76 mol%) under solvent-free condition, the product yield of 72 % was achieved (entry 5). When the model reaction was conducted in different solvents such as EtOH, PEG 400, ethylene glycol, glycerol, ChOAc/glycerol (1:2) and TBAB/glycerol (1:9 or 1:4), the desired product was obtained in moderate to good yields (entries 4, 7–10, 13 and 14). The use of H2O, ChCl/ethylene glycol (1:2) and ChCl/glycerol (1:2) as solvents led to significantly lower product yields (Table 1, entries 6, 11 and 12). Among the examined solvents, TBAB/glycerol (1:9) was found to be the most appropriate reaction medium in terms of the rate of reaction, product yield and environmental green chemistry for this catalytic system (entry 4). Furthermore, the efficiency of the nanocatalyst can be affected by varying the amount of catalyst used in the reaction. Addition of only 0.76 mol% of MNP-TIMPTC-CuI was sufficient to accomplish the reaction. Upon lowering the catalyst loadings to 0.58 and 0.39 mol %, the yields decreased respectively to 83 and 62 %, whereas the increase in the catalyst concentration to 0.98 and 1.17 mol% did not get better results (entries 15–18). Finally, the reaction efficiency was studied in the temperature range of 40−120 °C to obtain the optimum temperature (entries 19–22). According to the above results, the optimal conditions for this reaction consist of the use of MNP-TIMPTC-CuI (20 mg, 0.76 mol%) as the catalyst in TBAB/glycerol (1:9) at 110 °C for 4 h (entry 4). In order to explore the generality of this protocol, the scope of the reaction was extended to a variety of aldehydes, 2-aminopyridines and terminal alkynes using the optimized reaction conditions. According to the results shown in Table 2 , aromatic aldehydes with either electron‐donating or electron‐withdrawing groups at different positions on the ring as well as heteroaromatic aldehyde were well tolerated in this reaction. It is noteworthy that the position of the substituent groups on the benzene rings of the aldehydes affects the reaction slightly (Table 3 , entries 1–13). Similarly, good yields for the desired imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine products were obtained when cinnamaldehyde and isobutyraldehyde were employed as the aldehyde substrates in the reaction (Table 2, entries 14 and 15). To further probe the utility of these reaction conditions, terminal alkynes and 2-aminopyridines with either electron-deficient or electron-rich groups on the benzene rings were used as substrates, the reactions underwent smoothly to generate corresponding products in good yields (Table 2, entries 16–19). Moreover, the reaction was tested in the presence of ethyl propiolate as the alkyne substrate (Table 2, entries 20–22). The plausible mechanism for the synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines using the nanocatalyst (MNP-TIMPTC-CuI) in TBAB/glycerol (1:9) DES has been proposed on the basis of the literature review (Scheme 2 ). Initially, imine was formed through condensation of 2-aminopyridine with aldehyde assisted by DES (through hydrogen-bond interactions) (1). Then, the nucleophilic attack of alkyne, which was activated by copper catalyst, to imine leads to the formation of propargylamine (2). In the third stage, due to CH activation of alkyl triple bond by copper nanocatalyst as well as activation of NH in 2-aminopyridine moiety by DES (through hydrogen-bond interactions) (3), intramolecular cyclization in 5-exo-dig way occurred (4), which was followed by aromatic isomerization to afford the desired product in excellent yield (5). From the standpoint of ecological requirements for sustainable chemistry, the possibility of recovery and reusability of the catalyst and TBAB/glycerol (1:9) DES was investigated. For this purpose, the three-component reaction of phenylacetylene, benzaldehyde, and 2-aminopyridine was performed in the presence of MNP-TIMPTC-CuI under the optimum reaction conditions. After the completion of the reaction, the catalyst was easily separated from the reaction mixture using an external magnetic force, washed with ethanol for several times and dried under vacuum at 70 °C. Besides after the reaction mixture was cooled to ambient temperature, the reaction product was extracted with ethyl acetate and the mother liquor was evaporated under vacuum. The recovered mother liquor and catalyst were directly subjected to the fresh substrates for next cycle. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the catalyst could be reused for at least five times without appreciable loss of catalytic activity. Further, the composition and morphology of the recovered MNP-TIMPTC-CuI nanocatalyst was examined by EDX and FE-SEM analyses (Fig. 7b and c). As can be seen in Fig. (7 b), the EDX spectrum confirms the presence of the expected elements, including carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, silicon, sulfur, iron, copper, and iodine in the structure of the recovered catalyst. The comparison of SEM images of fresh catalyst and recovered catalyst indicated that the structure and morphology of catalyst almost remain intact after 5th run (Fig. 7c). In order to assay whether the Cu-incorporated nanocatalyst acts as a really heterogeneous catalyst under the reaction conditions of this protocol, hot filtration test was performed. In a typical experiment, the three-component reaction of 2-aminopyridine, benzaldehyde and phenylacetylene was conducted in the presence of MNP-TIMPTC-CuI under the optimum reaction conditions. The reaction was stopped after 2 h and the reaction mixture was cooled down to the room temperature. The nanocatalyst was magnetically removed from the reaction medium and the experiment was continued in absence of the catalyst under the same reaction conditions. The reaction showed no appreciable conversion even after 6 h, indicating the amount of leaching of the copper into the reaction mixture should be very low and that the catalyst acts heterogeneously in the reaction. Moreover, metal leaching from the nanocatalyst was investigated in the model reaction. After completion of the reaction, the catalyst was removed by magnetic filtration and Cu content of the filtrate was determined by ICP-OES analysis. It was observed no detectable Cu leaching after the first run. The amount of Cu leaching after five repeated recycling was found to be only 0.48 %. To assess the merit of the present protocol for the synthesis of imidazo [1,2-a]-pyridines via one-pot three-component reaction between 2-aminopyridines, aldehydes and alkynes, the result obtained using MNP-TIMPTC-CuI has been compared to some other related reports (Table 3). As can be seen in Table 3, employing the synthesized MNP-supported copper(I) catalyst in TBAB/glycerol (1:9) as a sustainable and green solvent has created more favorable reaction conditions leading to high yield of the desired product in shorter reaction time under lower catalyst loading with higher TON and TOF. Further, the magnetic catalyst can be readily separated and both the catalyst and solvent are able to recycle and reuse. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have successfully developed a novel, efficient, and eco-friendly catalytic approach using copper iodide immobilized on the magnetically retrievable mixed-donor organic ligand, containing carboxamide, imidazolidine-2-thione and imidazole-2-thione donor groups, in glycerol-based DES for the one-pot synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines via three-component reaction of 2-aminopyridines, aldehydes and alkynes. There has been a good cooperation between the MNP-TIMPTC-CuI nanocatalyst and TBAB/glycerol DES, leading to efficiently synthesize the desired products with high yields. The glycerol-based DES activates some reaction partners through hydrogen‐bond interactions as well as positions them in close proximity due to its favorable polarity and solubility. The catalyst system can be simply recovered by magnetic filtration and reused for at least five reaction cycles without an appreciable loss of catalytic activity. Higher TON, the use of a lower catalyst loading, durability to air, moisture and high temperature, lower E-factor, and the ability to recycle the solvent are some other merits of the present approach. coredata.dc:description: A Cu-incorporated nanocatalyst has been developed by immobilizing copper iodide on a magnetically retrievable mixed-donor ligand system, containing carboxamide, imidazolidine-2-thione and imidazole-2-thione donor groups and characterized by various analysis techniques such as FT-IR, XRD, FE-SEM, EDX elemental mapping, TEM, ICP-OES, TGA, and VSM. The versatility of the synthesized nanocatalyst has been demonstrated for the one-pot synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine derivatives via three-component reaction of 2-aminopyridines, aldehydes and alkynes using tetrabutyl ammonium bromide/glycerol (TBAB/glycerol) deep eutectic mixture as a sustainable medium. The nanocatalyst has exhibited high activity and stability under the reaction conditions with a negligible copper leaching, which can be due to the effective coordination interaction between the oxygen atom of carbonyl group as well as the sulfur atoms of thiocarbonyl groups in the supported ligand with copper iodide. The catalyst system can be readily recovered and successfully reused at least five times. Eco-friendly conditions, solvent recoverability, higher TON, wide functional group tolerance and lower E factor (0.2) are some other merits of the present work.
coredata.dc:title: Magnetic nanostructure-anchored mixed-donor ligand system based on carboxamide and N-heterocyclic thiones: An efficient support of CuI catalyst for synthesis of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines in eutectic medium
